ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A fine-grained grasp of a fairly nuanced issue that I have never looked into
Learned in-depth about different theories of truth, then compared them to different forms of relativism. Really developed ability to engage with difficult texts at a higher level.
Overview of the different grounding views of Truth and conceptions of Relativism
how to grapple with hard questions

I learned about what truth is, how relativism can be formalized, and the domains of true and relative facts. More importantly, this class encouraged me to combine metaphysical, epistemological and linguistic principles to defend nuanced positions that were eye-opening.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very interesting course material that was organized really well with the in-class handouts. Only qualm is that discussion section was often difficult to participate in. It felt that a small subset of students had previous knowledge that allowed them to dominate conversations. This made participating somewhat daunting.

Good course, but challenging to get through at 9am; no fault of the professor, but it made course engagement substantially more difficult. 

Note that the one-page assignments present as easy, but are difficult to score well in. On these assignments, the professor is highly nit-pickyhe is less charitable than you'd expect, and will dock you on the smallest debatably minor details.
technically difficult, maybe more office hours would be good, but the class itself was incredibly interesting

Strengths: Prof Szabo is a great seminar leader, and the readings for this course were difficult in an educational manner and incredibly well-chosen. The workload also wasn't too bad: three short two-page responses and a final paper. Weaknesses: Perhaps a little too much of class time was focused on relativism (and on related positions that lacked rigor).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The instructor is incredibly organized, knowledgeable, and clear.

I would recommend if the student has a sufficient background/interest in analytic philosophy. This was one of the first analytic courses I took, and I would have been able to interact more and gain a better understanding of the material if I had more prior knowledge. The material is very challenging, but professor Szabo does a great job explaining it and facilitating discussion.
Yes. I recommend it if you have experience taking philosophy classes. You need to read and write at a pretty high level. That said, the material is interesting and Szabo is a very engaging professor.

Yes, but know what you're getting yourself into. The course essentially is a survey of a) all the major views grounding Truth, b) the different understandings of Relativism. Unless you're especially discerning and opinionated, it will show you that no standard view adequately defines Truth. Be extremely cautious of that "knowledge", and fight the urge to throw up your hands. As advice for all seminars, but especially this one: plant your stake deep in the ground, but be willing to move it. Don't be equally sympathetic to everything. Reject or defend the view presented.

If you're interested in this niche area of philosophy and eager to combine multiple sub-disciplines in your thought, this course is for you. Prof Szabo is a great professor who is engaging and masterful in argument.
